security_audit.summary: Legitimate bioinformatics tool for accessing cancer genomics data from the Sanger Institute COSMIC database. Contains Python download utility with filesystem write and network access to official Sanger domain. No malicious patterns detected. Behavior matches stated purpose.

low_findings.title: Command-line password exposure
low_findings.description: Password can be passed via --password CLI argument which may be visible in process listings or shell history. Line 184: `parser.add_argument('--password', help='COSMIC account password (will prompt if not provided)')`. An attacker with process access could read credentials from command line arguments.

low_findings.title: Download URL not validated
low_findings.description: The download URL from the API response is used directly without validation. Line 85: `download_url = response_data.get("url")`. An attacker who compromised the COSMIC API could redirect downloads to malicious servers, potentially serving malicious content.

low_findings.title: Files written to current directory
low_findings.description: Files are written to the current working directory without path sanitization. Line 103: `with open(output_filename, 'wb') as f:`. While os.path.basename() is used on line 61, output_filename can still specify relative paths like '../../../malicious/path' if not derived from basename().

content.value_statement: Access the worlds largest database of somatic mutations in cancer. Download curated cancer gene lists, mutational signatures, and mutation data for bioinformatics research and precision oncology.
actual_capabilities: Download cancer mutation data from COSMIC database
Access Cancer Gene Census with curated cancer gene lists
Retrieve mutational signature profiles for signature analysis
Query structural variants, gene fusions, and copy number alterations
Download drug resistance mutations with clinical annotations
Access sample metadata and tumor information
limitations: Requires free academic registration or commercial license from Sanger Institute
Large data files may take significant time to download
No built-in data analysis functions - downloads raw data files only

use_cases.title: Research somatic mutations
use_cases.description: Download and analyze mutation data for cancer research projects and publications.

use_cases.title: Build genomics pipelines
use_cases.description: Integrate COSMIC data into bioinformatics workflows for variant annotation and signature analysis.

use_cases.title: Support precision medicine
use_cases.description: Access curated cancer gene lists and resistance mutations to inform treatment decisions.

prompt_templates.title: Basic mutation search
prompt_templates.scenario: Find mutations in a specific gene
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the cosmic-database skill to download TP53 mutations from the COSMIC database. Read the data and identify the most common mutation types and their frequencies.

prompt_templates.title: Cancer gene analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Download the Cancer Gene Census from COSMIC using the cosmic-database skill. Create a summary of oncogenes versus tumor suppressor genes and their associated cancer types.

prompt_templates.title: Signature research
prompt_templates.prompt: Download the mutational signatures data from COSMIC using the cosmic-database skill. Explain the SBS, DBS, and ID signature categories and their biological significance.

prompt_templates.title: Resistance mutations
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the cosmic-database skill to download resistance mutation data. Analyze which genes show the most drug resistance mutations and what treatments are affected.

output_examples.input: Download TP53 mutations from COSMIC and show summary statistics
output: Primary cancer sites: Lung (23%), Colorectal (18%), Breast (15%)

best_practices: Use getpass for password input instead of command-line arguments to avoid credential exposure in shell history
Validate downloaded file integrity using checksums when available from COSMIC
Keep local copies of data for reproducibility since COSMIC updates quarterly and historical versions may differ
anti_patterns: Passing passwords directly on the command line where they are visible in process listings
Downloading entire COSMIC database when only specific files are needed
Using data without verifying the COSMIC version for reproducibility

faq.question: Is COSMIC data free to use?
faq.answer:: Academic users get free access with registration. Commercial use requires a license from QIAGEN.

faq.question: How large are COSMIC data files?
faq.answer: Core mutation files exceed several gigabytes. Plan for adequate storage before downloading.

faq.question: What genome assemblies are supported?
faq.answer: Both GRCh37 (hg19) and GRCh38 are available. GRCh38 is recommended for new projects.

faq.question: How often is COSMIC updated?
faq.answer: COSMIC releases quarterly updates with new data and annotations. Current version is v102.

faq.question: What file formats are available?
faq.answer: TSV, CSV for tabular data, and VCF for variant calls. Most files are gzip compressed.

faq.question: How does this skill compare to cBioPortal?
faq.answer: COSMIC focuses on mutation data while cBioPortal provides integrated multi-omics data from specific studies.
